Articles.Content:
Have you altered any of the settings in Trajectories?  Certain things like disabling the Cache option can seriously ramp up CPU usage.

Perhaps try removing the entire Trajectories folder and reinstalling it to reset all of its settings.

*1.3 update comes out*

*Falls out of chair*

17 hours ago, Murican_Jeb said:

*1.3 update comes out*

*Falls out of chair*

I jumped out of mine. Thanks ferram!! I've been working up such an urge

On 8/22/2017 at 11:34 PM, garwel said:

I wonder if KSP 1.3.1 will be released soon and will break FAR. It's becoming a tradition already.

Spoke too soon

17 minutes ago, Rayquaza said:

Spoke too soon

 

Cool thing though: it didn't break anything yet
So I've heard this version is better than the stock aerodynamic system, is that true and how good?

8 minutes ago, The-Doctor said:

So I've heard this version is better than the stock aerodynamic system, is that true and how good? 

They're hardly even comparable. FAR makes KSP vehicles behave as they would in a real world atmosphere, while stock is barely a caricature by comparison. Not only is FAR quite accurate, it allows you to use proper aerodynamic principles and get the expected results.

The flip side is that if you don't build following robust aerodynamic principles, your vehicle won't behave very well, while stock is rather forgiving.

The analysis tools included also help massively, as do the much expanded customisation options for various surfaces.

Personally I have a hard time playing stock after using FAR for so long. Naturally if all you have is a simple rocket there isn't a big difference, but anything where aerodynamics are very significant, for example larger rockets with stabilising fins, large re-entry vehicles or spaceplanes and you'll really see FAR shine.

Edited August 27, 2017 by Starlionblue

1 hour ago, Starlionblue said:

They're hardly even comparable. FAR makes KSP vehicles behave as they would in a real world atmosphere, while stock is barely a caricature by comparison. Not only is FAR quite accurate, it allows you to use proper aerodynamic principles and get the expected results.

The flip side is that if you don't build following robust aerodynamic principles, your vehicle won't behave very well, while stock is rather forgiving.

The analysis tools included also help massively, as do the much expanded customisation options for various surfaces.

Personally I have a hard time playing stock after using FAR for so long. Naturally if all you have is a simple rocket there isn't a big difference, but anything where aerodynamics are very significant, for example larger rockets with stabilising fins, large re-entry vehicles or spaceplanes and you'll really see FAR shine.

so large rockets and space planes act properly with FAR?

29 minutes ago, The-Doctor said:

so large rockets and space planes act properly with FAR?

I don't know about 100% accuracy, but certainly they act much more properly. FAR actually attempts to model accurately, and does so very well, while stock is rather sloppy when it comes to aero.

I don't think that FAR is on par with the CFD tools available to the likes of Airbus, Boeing and SpaceX, but IMHO a completely different and much more enjoyable KSP experience.

Edited August 27, 2017 by Starlionblue

44 minutes ago, The-Doctor said:

so large rockets and space planes act properly with FAR?

They will behave more accurately.  Be aware though that accurate aerodynamics may often be unintuitive.

On 22.08.2017 at 2:01 PM, raxo2222 said:

It seems like there is bug in "air req met" display.

What does Cy, spec. excess pwr or v*l/d actually measure?

@ferram4

Sorry for quoting myself like that, but you didn't explained few things in FAR flight data.

Also there is big with air requirement display.

 

How do I build plane, that can fly comfortably at 50m/s or even slower?

Edited August 27, 2017 by raxo2222

2 hours ago, raxo2222 said:

 

How do I build plane, that can fly comfortably at 50m/s or even slower?

Lots of wing surface. That's my two cents worth on the topic.

4 hours ago, Rodhern said:

Lots of wing surface. That's my two cents worth on the topic.

Well there is difference in areodynamics between long narrow triangle wings and wide rectangle ones even if they have same area

9 hours ago, Rodhern said:

Lots of wing surface. That's my two cents worth on the topic.

Not to be Captain Obvious, but (to the OP) you can also reduce the wing mass and strength in FAR. A plane to fly at very slow speeds can benefit from this so its huge wing area doesn't have a huge mass (needing more lift and hence more speed and defeating the point of the exercise) and if you're only going to fly it at very slow speeds you can presumably resist the urge to throw it around the sky in 8g maneuvers and rip the wings off.

5 hours ago, raxo2222 said:

Well there is difference in areodynamics between long narrow triangle wings and wide rectangle ones even if they have same area

At least if you're using FAR.
So I'm thinking of getting this mod out.  Anybody know how well the OPT mod flies with it?

6 minutes ago, skygunner58203 said:

Anybody know how well the OPT mod flies with it?

there is a patch, but I have not heard any feedback on it yet over in the OPT thread

Edited August 29, 2017 by Drew Kerman
OPT not OPM dammit

Hello everyone, 

I'm a far-addicted player, so, i was really pleased when far come out for 1.3.....

but suddenly i noticed severe fps drop, looking in the in-game console i found that there was a massive spamming of "Null Reference Exception"

looking deeper in the KSP.log, I found that FAR  was causing the issue....(I'm a noob in reading error logs, so i might be in mistake)

now, can someone help me in solving this issue?

thank you in advance and thank you Ferram4 for making this game so enjoyable

Sorry for my bad english guys : (

cheers: )
